text: Nancy Kain and I am the James Robison
professor of business administration at
the Harvard Business School I was born
in Chicago um I lived in Illinois and in
Maine and in Texas as a child went to
school in California came to Boston 25
years ago for two years and never left I
think of myself as a
traveler um that was how I intended to
answer the first question who are you
and I had not connected it to a
childhood that included a lot of stops
along the journey but I
think living in so many different parts
of the country and seeing so many
different ways of life um probably did
affect my interest in traveling through
the past and into the present um I'm
very comfortable with tr traving
without a set destination and that may
have something to do with being a child
that you know changed school so many
times until until I reached sixth grade
I think I was in a different school
every year so maybe that proclivity to
travel metaphorically um is part of who
I am as a professional and as a human uh
traveler as a traveler on a life journey
I I don't think there was a pivotal
moment in my childhood I if I if I was
asked to think about a critical point or
a juncture it would be in my adult life
and whether that that moment or those
moments you know hearkened back or had a
tap rot into older points along my
childhood Journey May indeed be so but
I'm less conscious of them and and a
piece of that is is um an
increasing impatience PA with
living in the past which I think even as
a historian being paid to do that in
many ways I have spent as a human
traveler too much time doing so I
perhaps my mental operating system my my
you know my desktop if you will has just
more file folders that are closer in
time to this moment than it does moments
in my childhood my father was a very
important influence in my life um I
thought for most of my adult life thus
far that he was much more important than
my mother but I think now uh in my
middle age and I feel like I'm aging as
I speak my mother was very important
also my father as a role model
professionally he was a philosopher um
and he was a very athletic man and that
was incredibly important to me growing
up and still is he was a Driven Man and
I think for good and less good I took
some of my drive and my
natural operating system from him and
his
intensity um from my mother I actually
gained more subtle gifts
um uh an eye for the large
landscape for the large landscape of a
time for the large
landscape of of a of a moment or a
situation for the large landscape of of
Our Lives she's a she has a wide angle
lens on her and I took a long time to
realize how much of that I've benefited
from I thought I would be a child
psychologist I thought I would help um
parents and kids
understand why young people do what they
do ironically my father really talked me
out of majoring in Psychology when I was
a sophomore at
Stanford and he was a formidable person
in my life and I followed his guide
posts his sign posts um I think probably
with some real Discord inside me but
nevertheless I followed them
